image.altText: A young man with his blond hair combed back smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: The headmaster of Shore School in Sydney has been criticised over a newsletter he wrote describing Lilie James's accused murderer as an "absolute delight".

title.children: Elite Sydney school principal criticised for saying Lilie James's accused killer is 'not a monster'

image.altText: soldiers advancing in smoke

items.synopsis: With its troops sweeping through Gaza, Israel has been unafraid to exploit its enormous advantages — and the Palestinian death toll is climbing. But Israelis may be about to face a new threat, writes Eric Tlozek.

title.children: After a week of destruction in Gaza, the Palestinian death toll is climbing — and Israelis are facing a new threat

image.altText: man walks among rubble

items.synopsis: Hezbollah's leader gives a much-anticipated address warning that a wider conflict in the Middle East was possible if clashes continue on the Israel-Lebanon border.

title.children: Israel rules out ceasefire as Hezbollah warns of regional war

image.altText: Young baby at Childcare, Queenstown

items.synopsis: Adel Farr was prepared to leave her beloved west coast community in Tasmania to follow her career aspirations of working with children. Then she found out she didn't have to.

title.children: In this remote part of Australia, there's a dire shortage of childcare services. The community is doing its bit to address the challenge

image.altText: A young man with round face, wearing a beige shirt and camouflage jacket, is escorted as cameras flash nearby

items.synopsis: In a remote island community in the Philippines, a young man convinced villagers he was their saviour. Now, he is accused of leading a doomsday cult and fostering child marriages, rape, forced labour and human trafficking.

title.children: After a devastating earthquake struck this village, a charismatic young man promised paradise. Those that followed him found hell

image.altText: hands holding a photo of a dead floating dolphin

items.synopsis: Three dead dolphins turn up in an oil spill. The energy company says it's got nothing to do with it, but Alex, an insider, sets out to prove it wrong. Now, an ABC investigation has revealed mistakes were made.

title.children: How the death of three dolphins put one employee on the warpath with Santos

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Scott Morrison

items.synopsis: When he gets off the plane in China, not being Scott Morrison will help Anthony Albanese, but it only goes so far in stabilising relations in the long term, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: Albanese got a jump start on the world stage thanks to his predecessor

image.altText: Red flames light up the night sky.

items.synopsis: More than 300 people were forced to evacuate when a huge fire ripped through dozens of homes in the southern Queensland community of Tara. Now the residents are coming to grips with the devastation while looking to the future.

title.children: Johann woke to kelpie Mickey barking at something outside. He took this photo then fled for his life

image.altText: Justice Gregory Geason photographed in court.

items.synopsis: The state's Attorney-General says he is taking the matter "very seriously" and the Chief Justice has asked the judge, whom the ABC understands to be Gregory Geason, to take leave "until further notice".

title.children: Tasmanian Supreme Court judge stood down in relation to 'significant matter'

image.altText: A group of solar panels on a roof through the frame of leafy trees.

items.synopsis: While most Australians are stuck with inflated fixed-rate power prices, some are saving money by playing the spot market. So how are they doing it, and why isn't it for everyone?

title.children: Consumers tapping the spot power market are cleaning up, covering 'a month's bill' in a night

image.altText: Alisha Boe (left) wears a white 1870s wedding dress as she cheerses to four other women in emerald gowns.

items.synopsis: We've got an eerie Tiger King vibes outback mystery, we've got a swoon-worthy period drama, we've got titillatingly erotic stories, and we've got the identical twin dating show you didn't know you needed. Here are our top five new-to-streaming shows this month.

title.children: You can stop flicking aimlessly through streamers. Here are five new shows we think you’ll love

image.altText: Jackie Fahey, Grace Lam, Jodie Barber, Sharon Marlow and Liz Depers

items.synopsis: Women are being thrust back to the most severe stages of menopause amid long-running shortages of hormone replacement therapy patches.

title.children: Women bursting into tears at chemists as months-long hormone replacement patch shortage takes its toll

image.altText: A Fijian man dressed in Israeli attire

items.synopsis: Six Pacific Island countries have voted with Israel to oppose the UN resolution for a ceasefire in Gaza. For many nations in the region, the connection to Israel runs deep.

title.children: 'I believe it': The 'lost tribes' of Israel theory runs deep in the Pacific, as modern conflict sparks division

image.altText: A man works in a furnace wearing protective equipment.

items.synopsis: One of the world's biggest mining companies is pulling out of Australian copper despite growing demand for the renewable energy metal. What does that mean for Australia's role plugging the critical minerals gap?

title.children: Glencore is ditching Australian copper. What does it mean for our critical minerals industry?

image.altText: Lightning appears through a black storm cloud

items.synopsis: There has been a marked shift in the weather pattern across eastern Australia during the past 48 hours. The result will be a week-long spell of showers and thunderstorms from tropical Queensland to eastern Victoria.

title.children: Week-long spell of rain and storms for eastern states as north and west swelter

image.altText: Kandinsky's painting Composition 8, which feature an array of coloured geometric shapes seemingly floating in space.

items.synopsis: The AGNSW's international art series returns for Summer with the biggest Kandinsky retrospective ever mounted in Australia, featuring works never before seen works.

title.children: Nazis called him 'degenerate', historians call him 'pioneer': Kandinsky reflected a world in chaos

image.altText: A picture of Matthew Perry with the text "the one where we lost a friend" and a broken heart emoji in a bouquet of flowers

items.synopsis: I've been ineffably sad ever since the awful news of Matthew Perry's death. The first fatal rupture within an iconic cultural group — a band, an acting ensemble — is the true death of the group itself, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: I lived in the iconic 'Friends' apartment and I loved Chandler most. I'm ineffably sad about Matthew Perry's death

image.altText: The back of a women looking down a dark hallway in shadows

items.synopsis: The apparent suicide of a Tasmanian mother of three 13 years ago is being re-examined in an inquest, with the coroner's court hearing the woman's husband had had an affair and was later convicted of fraud.

title.children: 'Happy-go-lucky' mother of three's apparent suicide re-examined 13 years later

image.altText: Man smashing windows of shopfront

items.synopsis: Staff at a Tasmanian real estate agency were "shaken and upset" after several plate glass windows were smashed by a hammer-wielding man — as new police data shows crime in the state has bounced back after a lull during COVID.

title.children: Staff capture moment man smashes office windows with hammer

image.altText: A man stands in front of a brick wall.

items.synopsis: Ashwin Ramachandran is on a mission to help increase access to fertility tests for men and start more conversations about male infertility.

title.children: 'That freaked me out': How Ashwin's uncle's $130,000 IVF journey inspired him to start a company to help infertile men

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: A beef wellington lunch allegedly led to three deaths and a small south-east Victorian community in shock. Now the host has been charged with murder. Here's how it all unfolded.

title.children: How a sleepy Gippsland town made global headlines after a mushroom lunch allegedly killed three guests

image.altText: The Beatles during a photo session in Twickenham, 9 April 1969

items.synopsis: Processing a new song from a band that looms so large is a complex undertaking.

title.children: 'Mixed feelings': Fans weigh in following release of The Beatles' final ever song

image.altText: A woman soccer player wearing a yellow and green jersey with a blue bib poses for a photo with fans wearing yellow in a crowd

items.synopsis: Packed stadiums, paparazzi photos, and signs begging for jerseys: Like Taylor Swift, the Matildas have become superstars. So what does it mean going forward, asks Samantha Lewis.

title.children: The Matildas are entering their Swift Era, so what does that mean for them and for us?

image.altText: Peter Tully, who uses a wheelchair, wears a blue button up shirt at a train station.

items.synopsis: Around a quarter of Queenslanders with a disability have reported bad or very bad experiences catching public transport, but a raft of upgrades are on the way.

title.children: From breaking disability access law to future plans — here's how Queensland's trains are tracking

image.altText: A brown skinned woman and man stand next to each other outside a weatherboard house, the woman is holding a black dog.

items.synopsis: Neil Para and his family lived in Australia for more than nine years with no visa and no rights. What's life like now they've been granted permanent residency?

title.children: After almost 10 years living with no rights, permanent residency allows Para family to finally look to the future

image.altText: Amelie Borg sings the Port Adelaide theme song alongside Erin Phillips and Justine Mules

items.synopsis: Amelie Borg was just 17 when she was drafted to play AFLW alongside her idols at Port Adelaide, and hasn't missed a game since. She tells Kate O'Halloran why she never dreamed of being a footballer, and didn't bother watching the draft.

title.children: 'Hectic': How Amelie Borg managed to finish Year 12 while playing in her first AFLW season

image.altText: Ikram Alikhil is held up by Afghanistan teammates

items.synopsis: Afghanistan has four wins at the Cricket World Cup and remain an outside chance of making the semifinals after a low-scoring victory over the Netherlands.

title.children: Afghanistan still in the hunt for unlikely semifinal spot at Cricket World Cup

image.altText: Two women sit side by side, with one comforting the other.

items.synopsis: Advocates say WA's juvenile detention system is broken, and the government continues to fall back on empty rhetoric and platitudes. These are the questions they want it to answer.

title.children: 'A necessary evil': Asking the WA government the hardest questions on youth detention

image.altText: Abbey Wehrung shapes to shoot

items.synopsis: After losing her mother to breast cancer, Bendigo Spirit guard Abigail Wehrung spent 11 days trekking 260 kilometres on horseback to help raise money. It's that personal resilience that has helped the 27-year-old achieve on the court.

title.children: Abigail Wehrung's long trek from personal tragedy to three-point queen of the WNBL and Bendigo Spirit

image.altText: A middle-aged man with dark hair and wearing a navy shirt sits in a stairwell with his hands clenched together

items.synopsis: The bestselling author of Boy Swallows Universe returns with Lola in the Mirror, a sweeping love story infused with magical realism set against Brisbane's gritty underbelly.

title.children: ​​'As raw as if it happened yesterday': Trent Dalton explores childhood trauma in new novel

image.altText: Pat Cummins smiles

items.synopsis: Australia captain Pat Cummins says Australia still has enough firepower to beat England despite losing Mitch Marsh and Glenn Maxwell, while Ben Stokes wants England to put its 'crap' tournament behind them to beat their old rivals.

title.children: Pat Cummins says England's form is 'sad', Ben Stokes says it's been 'crap'

image.altText: A woman standing in a burnt out farm.

items.synopsis: Mrs Mitchell remained positive even when "eight-foot high" flames started rushing across her pastures. She knew that "once it got into the mowed area it would be simple to put out".

title.children: Despite '8-foot-high' flames rushing towards her property, 88-year-old Del Mitchell managed to save her cattle

image.altText: Latrell Mitchell and Jack Wighton smile while walking.

items.synopsis: ACT Policing has confirmed it will hold an internal review into the dropped prosecution of NRL stars Jack Wighton and Latrell Mitchell, but the public will likely never hear the result — and that is the standard.

title.children: 'Gone are the days of secret-squirrel organisations': Calls to lift the veil of secrecy over internal police reviews

image.altText: A bald man in a blue jumper smiles.

items.synopsis: Having worked on construction sites since he was a teenager, Joel Anderson was used to hearing phrases like "have a cup of concrete and harden up", which led him to launch his own mental health platform designed for blue-collar workers.

title.children: Construction workers are more likely to die by suicide than a work accident. Joel wants to change that statistic

image.altText: An Aboriginal man stands in front of trees

items.synopsis: The "globally significant" project will store up to 400,000 tonnes per annum of toxic waste, including low-level radioactive material from Australia and overseas.

title.children: Reggie wants to see change for his community. He hopes an underground toxic waste storage facility will help
